sentence.text: Patient 1 was born to remotely consanguineous Greek parents.
She had short stature, short limbs, brachydactyly, dolichocephaly, frontal bossing, ptosis, micrognathia, high palate, low-set ears, fine sparse hair and dysplastic nails (Fig. 1a,b).
Craniosynostosis was surgically corrected at the age of 2 months.
Psychomotor development was retarded (walking at age 16 months and talking at age 2 years).

X-ray examinations revealed narrow thorax with dysplastic ribs, bowed femora with abnormal epiphyses, short ulnae, brachydactyly, short metacarpals, short and bowed tibiae, short metatarsals and a triphalangeal hallux (Fig. 1c-e).
Chronic renal failure was noticed in the first year of life.
A brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan at the age of 2 years revealed a large cisterna magna and slight cortical atrophy.
